facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 189 of 1966 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 189 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal brought by special leave from judgment and order dated July 4, 1966 of Patna High Court in Criminal J.C. No. 11 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 4, 1966 of the Patna High Court in Criminal J.C. No. 11 of 1966.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Hegde J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Hegde J.

facts.text: Appeal against decision of Patna High Court in Criminal W.J.C. No. 11 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal against the decision of the High Court of Patna in Criminal W.J.C. No. 11 of 1966 was brought after obtaining special leave

facts.text: Appellants are office bearers of M/s S.K.G. Sugar, Ltd., Lauriya.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are office bearers of M s. S.K.G. Sugar, Ltd. Lauriya .

facts.text: A complaint has been registered against the appellants under sub-rule 3 of rule 3 of Sugarcane Control Order, 1955 read with s. 7 of the Essential Commodities Act, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: A companyplaint has been registered against them under sub-rule  3   of rule 3 of Sugarcane  Control  Order, 1955  to be hereinafter referred to as the Order  read with s. 7 of the Essential Commodities Act, 1955

facts.text: Appellants failed to pay to the sellers the price of the sugarcane purchased by them within the time prescribed.

anchor.surface_text: on the ground that they have failed to pay to the sellers the price of the sugarcane purchased by them, within the time prescribed.

facts.text: The said complaint is being investigated.

anchor.surface_text: The said companyplaint is being investigated.

facts.text: Appellants unsuccessfully sought intervention of Patna High Court under Art. 226 in Cr. W.J.C. No. 11 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: They unsuccessfully sought the intervention of the High Court of Patna under Art. 226 of the Constitution in Cr. W.I.C. No. 11 of 1966.

facts.text: Sugarcane Control Order, 1955 issued on 27th August, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Sugar Control Order, 1955 which was issued by the Central Government on 27th August, 1955, it also issued the Sugarcane Control Order, 1955, on the same date

facts.text: Bihar Sugar Factories Control Act, 1937 exists and regulates price of sugarcane.

anchor.surface_text: the regulation of the price of sugarcane is expressly dealt with by the Bihar Sugar Factories Control Act, 1937

facts.text: Sub-rule 3 of rule 3 of Sugarcane Control Order requires payment within 14 days unless agreement to contrary.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-rule  3  of rule 3 specifically provides that unless there is an agreement in writing to the companytrary between the parties the purchaser shall pay to the seller the price of the sugarcane purchased within 14 days from the date of the delivery of the sugarcane.

facts.text: Previous case: Ch. Tika Ramji and Ors. etc. v. The State of U.P. and Ors., 1956 S.C.R. 432.

anchor.surface_text: The question whether the cultivation and sale of sugarcane can be regulated under s. 3 of the Act came up for the companysideration of this Court in Ch. Tika Ramji and Ors. etc. v. The State of U.P. and Ors.  1  At pages 432 and 433 of the report

facts.text: No court has yet taken cognizance of the offence.

anchor.surface_text: No companyrt has yet taken companynizance of the case. That stage has Still to companye.

facts.text: Offence complained of is punishable with three years imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: The offence companyplained of is punishable with three years imprisonment and as such it falls within the 2nd Sch. of the Cr. P.C.

facts.text: Offence is cognizable as per Second Schedule of Cr.P.C. and s.4(1)(f).

anchor.surface_text: and companysequently the same is a companynizable offence as defined in s. 4 1  f  of the Cr. P.C. Hence it was open to the police to investigate the same.

anchor.surface_text: A. Seyid Muhammad and S.P. Nayar, for respondent No. 1.

issues.text: whether the investigation which is being carried on against the appellants under sub-rule 3 of rule 3 of Sugarcane Control Order, 1955 read with s. 7 of the Essential Commodities Act, 1955 is in accordance with law

anchor.surface_text: The principal question raised herein is whether the investigation which is being carried on against the appellants under sub-rule  3   of rule 3 of Sugarcane  Control  Order, 1955  to be hereinafter referred to as the Order  read with s. 7 of the Essential Commodities Act, 1955  to be hereinafter referred to as the Act  is in accordance with law.

issues.text: whether sub-rule 3 of rule 3 could have been validly issued under s. 3 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The 1st contention of Mr. Iyengar was that sub-rule  3  of rule 3 could number have been validly issued under s. 3 of the Act. According to him the said s. 3 cannot be used for companytrolling the payment of the price of food crops it can only deal with foodstuffs food crops are outside its scope.

issues.text: whether the regulation of the price of sugarcane is expressly dealt with by the Bihar Sugar Factories Control Act, 1937 and therefore the same power from the provisions of the Order and the Act should not be impliedly spelled out

anchor.surface_text: It was next contended by Mr. Iyengar that the regulation of the price of sugarcane is expressly dealt with by the Bihar Sugar Factories Control Act, 1937 and therefore we should number impliedly spell out the same power from the provisions of the Order and the Act.

issues.text: whether the Parliament had competence to enact any law relating to the control of sugarcane as that subject is within the exclusive legislative jurisdiction of the State, the same being a part of agriculture

anchor.surface_text: The next contention of the learned Counsel for the appellants was that the Parliament had numbercompetence to enact any law relating to the companytrol of sugarcane as that subject is within the exclusive legislative jurisdiction of the State, the same being a part of agriculture.

issues.text: whether the impugned order contravenes the fundamental right guaranteed to the citizens under Art. 19(1)

anchor.surface_text: There is numbersubstance in the contention that the impugned order contravenes the fundamental right guaranteed to the citizens under Art. 19  1  . No fundamental right is conferred on a buyer not to pay the price of the goods purchased by him or to pay the same whenever he pleases.

issues.text: whether in view of s. 11 of the Act, no cognizance could have been taken of the offence alleged

anchor.surface_text: The contention that in view of s. 11 of the Act, no cognizance could have been taken of the offence alleged is premature. This question does not arise in this case. No court has yet taken cognizance of the case.

issues.text: whether the complaint made before the police does not disclose a cognizable offence and as such the police could not have taken up the investigation

anchor.surface_text: There is no substance in the contention that the complaint made before the police does number disclose a Cognizable offence and as such the police companyld number have taken up the investigation of that companyplaint. The offence companyplained of is punishable with three years imprisonment and as such it falls within the 2nd Sch. of the Cr. P.C.

arguments.claim: sub-rule 3 of rule 3 validly issued under s.3; sugarcane within ambit of Act via s.2(a)(v), s.2(b), s.3(1)(b)(c)

anchor.surface_text: Section 2 a  of the Act defines essential companymodity. Sub-cl.  v  of that clause brings foodstuffs within the definition of essential companymodity. Clause  b  of s. 2 provides that food-crops include sugarcane. The next important provisions in the Act are cls.  b  and  c  of s. 3 1 .

arguments.claim: cultivation and sale of sugarcane can be regulated under s.3 of the Act

arguments.court_reasoning: Binding precedent in Tika Ramji upholds regulation including Sugarcane Control Order

arguments.claim: Sub-rule 3 of rule 3 specifically provides payment within 14 days unless agreement to contrary; Bihar Act altered by Sugarcane Control Order under Art.372

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Iyengar is number right in companytending that the power that is sought to be exercised in the instant case is an implied one. Sub-rule  3  of rule 3 specifically provides that unless there is an agreement in writing to the companytrary between the parties the purchaser shall pay to the seller the price of the sugarcane purchased within 14 days from the date of the delivery of the sugarcane.

arguments.claim: Parliament competent under Entry 33 List III; Central Govt competent to issue Sugarcane Control Order

anchor.surface_text: This companytention is again unsustainable in view of Entry 33 of List III of the Constitution which empowers the Parliament to legislate in respect of production, supply and distribution of foodstuffs. It is number disputed that the Parliament had declared-by law that it is expedient in public interest that it should exercise companytrol over foodstuffs.

arguments.court_reasoning: Offence punishable with 3 years imprisonment; falls in 2nd Sch CrPC; cognizable per s.4(1)(f) CrPC; police open to investigate

arguments.claim: offence cognizable; police entitled to investigate

anchor.surface_text: The offence companyplained of is punishable with three years imprisonment and as such it falls within the 2nd Sch. of the Cr. P.C. and companysequently the same is a companynizable offence as defined in s. 4 1  f  of the Cr. P.C. Hence it was open to the police to investigate the same.

holdings.text: There is no merit in the contention that sub-rule 3 of rule 3 could not have been validly issued under s. 3 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: This contention has been negatived by the High Court. We agree with the High Court that there is no merit in this contention. Section 2 a  of the Act defines essential commodity. Sub-cl. v  of that clause brings foodstuffs within the definition of essential commodity. Clause  b  of s. 2 provides that food-crops include sugarcane. The next important provisions in the Act are cls.  b  and  c  of s. 3 1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies statutory definitions in s.2(a)(v) and s.2(b) including sugarcane as food-crop; s.3(1)(b)(c) empowers regulation of cultivation and price control; follows Tika Ramji precedent upholding regulation of sugarcane

holdings.text: The power exercised is a specific mandate under sub-rule 3 of rule 3 and the Bihar Sugar Factories Control Act, 1937 stands altered under Art. 372 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Iyengar is not right in contending that the power that is sought to be exercised in the instant case is an implied one. Sub-rule  3  of rule 3 specifically provides that unless there is an agreement in writing to the contrary between the parties the purchaser shall pay to the seller the price of the sugarcane purchased within 14 days from the date of the delivery of the sugarcane.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sub-rule provides explicit payment timeline; pre-Constitution Bihar Act continues only until altered by competent authority, which Central Government Order did

holdings.text: Parliament is competent to enact laws relating to control of sugarcane under Entry 33 of List III

anchor.surface_text: This contention is again unsustainable in view of Entry 33 of List III of the Constitution which empowers the Parliament to legislate in respect of production, supply and distribution of foodstuffs. It is not disputed that the Parliament had declared-by law that it is expedient in public interest that it should exercise control over foodstuffs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent legislative power under Entry 33 List III post Third Amendment; Parliament declared public interest control over foodstuffs including sugarcane

holdings.text: The impugned order does not contravene fundamental rights under Art. 19(1)

anchor.surface_text: There is no substance in the contention that the impugned order contravenes the fundamental right guaranteed to the citizens under Art. 19 1 . No fundamental right is conferred on a buyer not to pay the price of the goods purchased by him or to pay the same whenever he pleases.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No fundamental right exists for a buyer to delay payment of price for purchased goods

holdings.text: Contention regarding s. 11 of the Act preventing cognizance is premature as no court has taken cognizance

anchor.surface_text: The contention that in view of s. 11 of the Act, no cognizance could have been taken of the offence alleged is premature. This question does not arise in this case. No court has yet taken cognizance of the case. That stage has Still to come.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No court has taken cognizance yet; issue arises only at that stage

holdings.text: The offence discloses a cognizable offence and police are entitled to investigate

anchor.surface_text: There is no substance in the contention that the complaint made before the police does not disclose a Cognizable offence and as such the police could not have taken up the investigation of that complaint. The offence complained of is punishable with three years imprisonment and as such it falls within the 2nd Sch. of the Cr. P.C.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Punishable with three years imprisonment, falls under 2nd Schedule CrPC making it cognizable per s.4(1)(f) CrPC allowing police investigation

holdings.text: The investigation against the appellants under sub-rule 3 of rule 3 of Sugarcane Control Order, 1955 read with s. 7 of the Essential Commodities Act, 1955 is in accordance with law

anchor.surface_text: The principal question raised herein is whether the investigation which is being carried on against the appellants under sub-rule  3   of rule 3 of Sugarcane  Control  Order, 1955  to be hereinafter referred to as the Order  read with s. 7 of the Essential Commodities Act, 1955  to be hereinafter referred to as the Act  is in accordance with law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects all contentions challenging validity, competence, rights violation, and propriety of investigation

precedents.citation: Ch. Tika Ramji and Ors. etc. v. The State of U.P. and Ors.  1 [1956 S.C.R. 432]

anchor.surface_text: Ch. Tika Ramji and Ors. etc. v. The State of U.P. and Ors.  1  At pages 432 and 433 of the report it is observed Act X of 1955 included within the definition of essential companymodity foodstuffs which we have seen above would include sugar as well as sugarcane.

precedents.case_name: Ch. Tika Ramji v. State of U.P.
precedents.cited_proposition: Sugarcane falls within the definition of food-crops and essential commodity under the Essential Commodities Act, 1955; Central Government has power under Section 3 to regulate its production, supply, distribution, trade, commerce and price under Entry 33 of List III.
precedents.cited_holding: These provisions would certainly bring within the scope of Central legislation the regulation of the production of sugarcane as also the controlling of the price at which sugarcane may be bought or sold, and in addition to the Sugar Control Order, 1955 ... Sugarcane Control Order, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: This contention has been negatived by the High Court. We agree with the High Court that there is no merit in this contention. Section 2 a  of the Act defines essential commodity. Sub-cl. v  of that clause brings foodstuffs within the definition of essential commodity. Clause  b  of s. 2 provides that food-crops include sugarcane. The next important provisions in the Act are cls.  b  and  c  of s. 3 1 .
For the reasons mentioned above we are unable to accept any of the companytention advanced on behalf of the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Iyengar is not right in contending that the power that is sought to be exercised in the instant case is an implied one. Sub-rule  3  of rule 3 specifically provides that unless there is an agreement in writing to the contrary between the parties the purchaser shall pay to the seller the price of the sugarcane purchased within 14 days from the date of the delivery of the sugarcane.
For the reasons mentioned above we are unable to accept any of the companytention advanced on behalf of the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: This contention is again unsustainable in view of Entry 33 of List III of the Constitution which empowers the Parliament to legislate in respect of production, supply and distribution of foodstuffs. It is not disputed that the Parliament had declared-by law that it is expedient in public interest that it should exercise control over foodstuffs.
For the reasons mentioned above we are unable to accept any of the companytention advanced on behalf of the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: There is no substance in the contention that the impugned order contravenes the fundamental right guaranteed to the citizens under Art. 19 1 . No fundamental right is conferred on a buyer not to pay the price of the goods purchased by him or to pay the same whenever he pleases.
For the reasons mentioned above we are unable to accept any of the companytention advanced on behalf of the appellants.
